title: According to Virgil Aeneid, what does it mean to be a Roman? - Quora

response.answer_text: To answer that homework question, you need to look at The Aeneid in the section in which Aeneas visits the underworld and chats with his deceased father, Anchises. After a long catalog of future Roman heroes, generals, leaders, and orators, Anchises pauses his speech. He does a quick contrast between the skills of Rome and the skills of the Greeks and Persians. He indicates other people will be good at sculpture, or oratory, or astronomy. However, Romans will have one special talent that they are best at, which defines them uniquely. For the first time in the poem, Virgil refers to Aeneas and the Trojan people as Romans specifically, after they hear their mandate from Jupiter. Read that section, and you’ll see what Virgil thinks it means to be a Roman.

He said Romulus killing Remis by a river in Italy is what va Roman is or they would be called Remans. However, rejecting the Monarchy system of the Etruscans and beginning a Republic in 509BCE is more what you were asking?
